info.title: Lambda Cloud API
info.description:
The Lambda Cloud API provides a set of REST API endpoints you can use to create
and manage your Lambda Cloud resources.

Requests to the API are generally limited to one request per second. Requests to
the `/instance-operations/launch` endpoint are limited to one request per 12
seconds, or five requests per minute.

## Response types and formats {#formats}

The format of each response object depends on whether the request succeeded or failed.

### Success responses {#success-responses}

When a request succeeds, the API returns a response object in the following format. `<PAYLOAD>`
represents the endpoint-specific data object returned as part of the response object.

```json
{
    "data": <PAYLOAD>
}
```

### Error responses {#error-responses}

When a request fails, the API returns an error response object in the following format:

```json
{
    "error": {
        "code": string,
        "message": string,
        "suggestion": string?
    }
}
```

- `code`: A machine- and human-readable error code specific to a particular failure mode.
- `message`: An explanation of the error.
- `suggestion`: When present, a suggestion for how to address the error.

:::note{type="info" title="Note"}
When handling errors, avoid relying on the values of `message` or `suggestion`, as
these values are subject to change. Instead, use the value of `code`.
:::

#### Provider errors {#provider-errors}

In some cases, you might receive errors that come from upstream services/providers rather than directly
from Lambda services. You can identify these errors by their error code prefix, `provider/`.

Common provider errors include:

- Network outages or connectivity issues
- Service unavailability
- Quota limitations or resource exhaustion

An example of a typical service unavailability error:

```json
{
  "error": {
    "code": "provider/internal-unavailable",
    "message": "Provider unavailable",
    "suggestion": "Try again shortly"
  }
}
```

## Authentication {#authentication}


The Lambda Cloud API uses API keys to authenticate incoming requests. You
can generate a new API key pair or view your existing API keys by visiting
the [API keys page](https://cloud.lambda.ai/api-keys) in the Lambda Cloud
dashboard.


In general, Lambda recommends passing an HTTP Bearer header that contains
your API key:

```http
Authorization: Bearer <YOUR-API-KEY>
```

### Authenticating with `curl` {#authenticating-with-curl}

The API also supports passing an HTTP Basic header. This option chiefly exists
to support `curl`'s `-u` flag, which allows you to pass your credentials
without having to write out the full `Authorization: Basic` header string.
For example:

```bash
curl --request GET --url 'https://cloud.lambda.ai/api/v1/instances' \
  --header 'accept: application/json' \
  --user '<YOUR-API-KEY>:'
```

If your use case requires it, you can also pass the HTTP Basic header directly.
The value you pass must be a Base64-encoded string containing your API key
and a trailing colon:

```http
Authorization: Basic <BASE64-ENCODED-API-KEY>:
```

:::note{type="attention" title="Important"}
If you make a request without including a supported `Authorization` header,
the request will fail.
:::

parameters.name: cluster_id

schema.description:
If provided, the resulting list will only include
            instances that are part of a cluster with this unique identifier (ID).

parameters.description:
If provided, the resulting list will only include
            instances that are part of a cluster with this unique identifier (ID).

get.description: Retrieves a list of your running instances.
Retrieves the details of a specific instance, including whether or not the instance is running.

post.description: Updates the details of the specified instance.

get.description: Retrieves a list of the instance types currently offered on Lambda's public cloud, as well as details about each type. Details include resource specifications, pricing, and regional availability.

post.description: Launches a Lambda On-Demand Cloud instance.

get.description: Retrieves a list of your SSH keys.

post.description:
Add an SSH key to your Lambda Cloud account. You can upload an existing public
key, or you can generate a new key pair.

-  To use an existing key pair, set the `public_key` property in the request body
   to your public key.

-  To generate a new key pair, omit the `public_key` property from the request
   body.

:::note{type="attention" title="Important"}
Lambda doesn't store your private key after it's been generated.
If you generate a new key pair, make sure to save the resulting private key locally.
:::

For example, to generate a new key pair and associate it with a Lambda
On-Demand Cloud instance:

1. Generate the key pair. The command provided below automatically extracts and
    saves the returned private key to a new file called `key.pem`. Replace
    `<NEW-KEY-NAME>` with the name you want to assign to the SSH key:

    ```bash
    curl --request POST --url 'https://cloud.lambda.ai/api/v1/ssh-keys' \
    --fail \
    --user ${LAMBDA_API_KEY}: \
    --data '{"name": "<NEW-KEY-NAME>"}' \
    | jq -r '.data.private_key' > key.pem
    ```

2. Next, set the private key's permissions to read-only:

    ```bash
    chmod 400 key.pem
    ```

3. Launch a new instance. Replace `<NEW-KEY-NAME>` with the name you assigned
   to your SSH key.

    ```bash
    curl --request POST 'https://cloud.lambda.ai/api/v1/instance-operations/launch' \
    --fail \
    --user ${LAMBDA_API_KEY}: \
    --data '{"region_name":"us-west-1","instance_type_name":"gpu_1x_a10","ssh_key_names":["<NEW-KEY-NAME>"],"file_system_names":[],"quantity":1,"name":"My Instance"}'
    ```

4. From your local terminal, establish an SSH connection to the instance.
   Replace `<INSTANCE-IP>` with the public IP of the instance:

    ```bash
    ssh -i key.pem <INSTANCE-IP>
    ```

parameters.name: id

schema.description: The unique identifier (ID) of the SSH key to delete

parameters.description: The unique identifier (ID) of the SSH key to delete

get.description: Retrieves a list of your filesystems.

parameters.name: id

schema.description: The unique identifier (ID) of the filesystem to delete

parameters.description: The unique identifier (ID) of the filesystem to delete

delete.description: Deletes the filesystem with the specified ID. The filesystem must not be mounted to any running instances at the time of deletion.

get.description: Retrieves a list of available images by region.

Retrieves a list of your firewall rules.

**Note:** Firewall rules do not apply to the **us-south-1** region.

put.description:
Overwrites the inbound firewall rules currently active for your account's instances with the desired rules.

**Note:** Firewall rules do not apply to the **us-south-1** region.

get.description: Retrieves a list of your firewall rulesets.

post.description: Creates a new firewall ruleset with the specified name and rules.

get.description: Retrieves the details of the global firewall ruleset.

patch.description: Updates the global firewall ruleset. This allows updating the rules only.

schema.description: An ISO 8601 timestamp defining the start of the time range to query, inclusive. If omitted, the response starts at the earliest available event.

parameters.description: An ISO 8601 timestamp defining the start of the time range to query, inclusive. If omitted, the response starts at the earliest available event.

get.description: Retrieves a list of audit events that have occurred in your account. To view the full catalog of possible audit events, visit [Access and security > Audit logs](https://docs.lambda.ai/public-cloud/access-security#audit-logs) in the Lambda Cloud documentation.

code.description: The unique identifier for the type of error.

message.default: API key was invalid, expired, or deleted.

suggestion.default: Check your API key or create a new one, then try again.
suggestion.description: One or more suggestions of possible ways to fix the error.

code.description: The unique identifier for the type of error.

suggestion.default: Make sure you have verified your email address and have a valid payment method. Contact Support if problems continue.
suggestion.description: One or more suggestions of possible ways to fix the error.

available.description: If set, indicates that the relevant operation can be performed on the instance in its current state.

reason_code.description: A code representing the instance state that is blocking the operation. Only provided if the operation is blocked.

reason_description.description: A longer description of why this operation is currently blocked. Only provided if the operation is blocked.

InstanceStatus.title: InstanceStatus
InstanceStatus.description: The current status of the instance.

mount_point.description: The absolute path indicating where on the instance the filesystem will be mounted.

file_system_id.description: The id of the filesystem to mount to the instance.

FilesystemMountEntry.title: FilesystemMountEntry
FilesystemMountEntry.description: The mount point for a filesystem mounted to an instance.

description.description: The location represented by the region code.

memory_gib.description: The amount of RAM in gibibytes (GiB).

storage_gib.description: The amount of storage in gibibytes (GiB).

name.description: The name of the instance type.

description.description: A description of the instance type.

gpu_description.description: The type of GPU used by this instance type.

price_cents_per_hour.description: The price of the instance type in US cents per hour.

specs.description: Detailed technical specifications for the instance type.

migrate.description:
Indicates whether the instance is currently able to be migrated.
If not, describes why the operation is blocked.

rebuild.description:
Indicates whether the instance is currently able to be rebuilt.
If not, describes why the operation is blocked.

restart.description:
Indicates whether the instance is currently able to be restarted.
If not, describes why the operation is blocked.

cold_reboot.description:
Indicates whether the instance is currently eligible for a cold reboot.
If not, describes why the operation is blocked.

terminate.description:
Indicates whether the instance is currently able to be terminated.
If not, describes why the operation is blocked.

id.description: The unique identifier of the firewall ruleset.
The unique identifier of the instance.

name.description: If set, the user-provided name of the instance.

ip.description: The public IPv4 address of the instance.

private_ip.description: The private IPv4 address of the instance.

ssh_key_names.description: The names of the SSH keys that are allowed to access the instance.

file_system_names.description: The names of the filesystems mounted to the instance. If no filesystems are mounted, this array is empty.

file_system_mounts.description:
The filesystems, along with the mount paths, mounted to
the instances. If no filesystems are mounted, this parameter
will be missing from the response.

region.description: The region in which the instance is deployed.

instance_type.description: Detailed information about the instance's instance type.

hostname.description: The hostname assigned to this instance, which resolves to the instance's IP.

jupyter_token.description: The secret token used to log into the JupyterLab server hosted on the instance.

jupyter_url.description: The URL that opens the JupyterLab environment on the instance.

actions.description: A set of status objects representing the current availability of common instance operations.

tags.description: Key/value pairs representing the instance's tags.

firewall_rulesets.description: The firewall rulesets associated with this instance.

code.description: The unique identifier for the type of error.

suggestion.description: One or more suggestions of possible ways to fix the error.

code.description: The unique identifier for the type of error.

suggestion.description: One or more suggestions of possible ways to fix the error.

name.description: The new, user-provided name for the instance.

instance_type.description: The description, technical specifications, and metadata for this instance type.

regions_with_capacity_available.description: A list of the regions in which this instance type is available.

InstanceTypesItem.title: InstanceTypesItem
InstanceTypesItem.description: Detailed information and regional availability for the instance type.

code.description: The unique identifier for the type of error.

suggestion.default: Make sure your billing address is valid. Contact Support if problems continue.
suggestion.description: One or more suggestions of possible ways to fix the error.

instance_ids.description: The unique identifiers (IDs) of the launched instances.

code.description: The unique identifier for the type of error.

suggestion.description: One or more suggestions of possible ways to fix the error.

message.default: Not enough capacity to fulfill launch request.

suggestion.description: One or more suggestions of possible ways to fix the error.

message.description: The resource the API was unable to find.

suggestion.description: One or more suggestions of possible ways to fix the error.

code.description: The unique identifier for the type of error.

suggestion.default: Contact Support to increase your quota.
suggestion.description: One or more suggestions of possible ways to fix the error.

mount_point.description: The absolute path indicating where on the instance the filesystem will be mounted.

file_system_id.description: The id of the filesystem to mount to the instance.

RequestedFilesystemMountEntry.title: RequestedFilesystemMountEntry
RequestedFilesystemMountEntry.description: The mount point for a filesystem mounted to an instance.

ImageSpecificationID.title: ImageSpecificationID
ImageSpecificationID.description: Specifies the image to use by its unique identifier.

family.description: The family name of the image.

ImageSpecificationFamily.title: ImageSpecificationFamily
ImageSpecificationFamily.description: Specifies the image to use by its family name.

region_name.description: The region into which you want to launch the instance.

instance_type_name.description:
The type of instance you want to launch. To retrieve a list of available instance types, see
[List available instance types](#listInstanceTypes).

ssh_key_names.description:
The names of the SSH keys you want to use to provide access to the instance.
Currently, exactly one SSH key must be specified.

file_system_names.description:
The names of the filesystems you want to mount to the instance. When specified
alongside `file_system_mounts`, any filesystems referred to in both lists will use the
mount path specified in `file_system_mounts`, rather than the default.

file_system_mounts.description:
The filesystem mounts to mount to the instance. When specified alongside
`file_system_names`, any filesystems referred to in both lists will use the
mount path specified in `file_system_mounts`, rather than the default.

hostname.description:
The hostname to assign to the instance. If not specified, a default, IP-address-based
hostname is assigned. This hostname is driven into /etc/hostname on the instance.

name.description: The name you want to assign to your instance. Must be 64 characters or fewer.

image.description: The machine image you want to use. Defaults to the latest Lambda Stack image.

user_data.description:
An instance configuration string specified in a valid
[cloud-init user-data](https://cloudinit.readthedocs.io/en/latest/explanation/format.html)
format. You can use this field to configure your instance on launch. The
user data string must be plain text and cannot exceed 1MB in size.

tags.description: Key/value pairs representing the instance's tags.

firewall_rulesets.description:
The firewall rulesets to associate with the instance.
The firewall rulesets must exist in the same region as the instance.

restarted_instances.description: The list of instances that were successfully restarted.

instance_ids.description: The unique identifiers (IDs) of the instances to restart.

terminated_instances.description: The list of instances that were successfully terminated.

instance_ids.description: The unique identifiers (IDs) of the instances to terminate.

id.description: The unique identifier (ID) of the SSH key.

name.description: The name of the SSH key.

public_key.description: The public key for the SSH key.

SSHKey.title: SSHKey
SSHKey.description:
Information about a stored SSH key, which can be used to access instances over
SSH.

id.description: The unique identifier (ID) of the SSH key.

name.description: The name of the SSH key.

public_key.description: The public key for the SSH key.

private_key.description:
The private key generated in the SSH key pair. Make sure to store a
copy of this key locally, as Lambda does not store the key server-side.

GeneratedSSHKey.title: GeneratedSSHKey
GeneratedSSHKey.description:
Information about a server-generated SSH key, which can be used to access instances over
SSH.

name.description: The name of the SSH key.

public_key.description: The public key for the SSH key.

id.description: The unique identifier for the user.

email.description: The email address of the user.

status.description: The status of the user's account.

User.title: User
User.description: Information about a user in your Team.

id.description: The unique identifier (ID) of the filesystem.

mount_point.description:
The DEFAULT absolute path indicating where on instances the filesystem will be mounted.
If `file_system_mounts` were used at launch time, the actual mount point is in the
instance response.

created.description: The date and time at which the filesystem was created. Formatted as an ISO 8601 timestamp.

created_by.description: The user in your Team that created the filesystem.

is_in_use.description:
Whether the filesystem is currently mounted to an instance. Filesystems that
are mounted cannot be deleted.

region.description: The region in which the filesystem is deployed.

bytes_used.description:
The approximate amount of storage used by the filesystem in bytes. This estimate is
updated every few hours.

code.description: The unique identifier for the type of error.

suggestion.description: One or more suggestions of possible ways to fix the error.

region.description: The region in which you want to create the filesystem.

deleted_ids.description: The unique identifiers of the filesystems that were deleted.

code.description: The unique identifier for the type of error.

suggestion.description: One or more suggestions of possible ways to fix the error.

code.description: The unique identifier for the type of error.

suggestion.description: One or more suggestions of possible ways to fix the error.

id.description: The unique identifier (ID) for an image.

created_time.description: The date and time that the image was created.

updated_time.description: The date and time that the image was last updated.

name.description: The human-readable identifier for an image.

family.description: The family the image belongs to.

architecture.description: The CPU architecture the image supports.

region.description: The region in which this image is available.

Image.title: Image
Image.description: An available machine image in Lambda Cloud.

protocol.description: The protocol to which the rule applies.

port_range.description:
An inclusive range of network ports specified as `[min, max]`.
Not allowed for the `icmp` protocol but required for the others.

To specify a single port, list it twice (for example, `[22,22]`).

source_network.description:
The set of source IPv4 addresses from which you want to allow inbound
traffic. These addresses must be specified in CIDR notation. You can
specify individual public IPv4 CIDR blocks such as `1.2.3.4` or
`1.2.3.4/32`, or you can specify `0.0.0.0/0` to allow access from any
address.

This value is a string consisting of a public IPv4 address optionally
followed by a slash (/) and an integer mask (the network prefix).
If no mask is provided, the API assumes `/32` by default.

description.description: A human-readable description of the rule.

data.description: The list of inbound firewall rules.

id.description: The unique identifier of the firewall ruleset.

name.description: The name of the firewall ruleset.

region.description: The region in which the firewall ruleset is deployed.

rules.description: The list of firewall rules in this ruleset.

created.description: The date and time at which the firewall ruleset was created. Formatted as an ISO 8601 timestamp.

instance_ids.description: The IDs of instances this firewall ruleset is associated with.

FirewallRuleset.title: FirewallRuleset
FirewallRuleset.description: A collection of firewall rules that can be associated with instances.

code.description: The unique identifier for the type of error.

suggestion.default: Try again later. Contact Support if the problem persists.
suggestion.description: One or more suggestions of possible ways to fix the error.

name.description: The name of the firewall ruleset.

region.description: The region in which the firewall ruleset is deployed.

rules.description: The firewall rules to include in the ruleset.

FirewallRulesetCreateRequest.title: FirewallRulesetCreateRequest
FirewallRulesetCreateRequest.description: Request to create a new firewall ruleset.

id.description: The unique identifier of the firewall ruleset.

name.description: The name of the firewall ruleset.

rules.description: The list of firewall rules in this ruleset.

GlobalFirewallRuleset.title: GlobalFirewallRuleset
GlobalFirewallRuleset.description: Global firewall rules apply to all instances.

rules.description: The new firewall rules for the ruleset. If not provided, the rules will not be updated.

GlobalFirewallRulesetPatchRequest.title: GlobalFirewallRulesetPatchRequest
GlobalFirewallRulesetPatchRequest.description: Request to update the global firewall ruleset.

code.description: The unique identifier for the type of error.

message.default: Firewall ruleset does not exist or you do not have permission to access it.

suggestion.default: Check your firewall ruleset ID and try again.
suggestion.description: One or more suggestions of possible ways to fix the error.

name.description: The new name for the firewall ruleset. If not provided, the name will not be updated.

rules.description: The new firewall rules for the ruleset. If not provided, the rules will not be updated.

FirewallRulesetPatchRequest.title: FirewallRulesetPatchRequest
FirewallRulesetPatchRequest.description: Request to partially update a firewall ruleset.

code.description: The unique identifier for the type of error.

message.default: Firewall ruleset is in use by one or more instances.

suggestion.default: Terminate all instances that are using the ruleset before deleting it.
suggestion.description: One or more suggestions of possible ways to fix the error.

service_name.description: The service in which the action was performed.

resource_name.description: The type of resource that was affected.

catalog_version.description: The version of the event catalog schema.

event_id.description: The unique identifier (ID) for this audit event.

event_time.description: The UTC timestamp for when the event occurred (ISO 8601 format).

actor_lrn.description: The Lambda Resource Name (LRN) of the actor who performed the action.

resource_lrns.description: The Lambda Resource Names (LRNs) of the resources affected by this action.

resource_owner_lrn.description: The Lambda Resource Name (LRN) of the account that owns the affected resources.

request_api_key_lrn.description: The Lambda Resource Name (LRN) of the API key used to authenticate the request, if applicable.

additional_details.description: Additional event-specific details. The exact keys returned vary by event type.

AuditEvent.title: AuditEvent
AuditEvent.description:
Audit event in the account's audit log. To view the full catalog of
possible audit events, visit
[Access and security > Audit logs](https://docs.lambda.ai/public-cloud/access-security#audit-logs)
in the Lambda Cloud documentation.

page_token.description: A page token. Provide this token in your next request to retrieve the next page of results. If there are no additional pages, this field has a null value.

AuditEventsPage.title: AuditEventsPage
AuditEventsPage.description: A paginated response containing audit events.

basicAuth.description:
Basic HTTP authentication. Allowed headers:
  * `Authorization: Basic <base64 encoding of api_key>:`
  * `Authorization: Basic <api_key>`

bearerAuth.description:
Bearer HTTP authentication. Allowed headers:
  * `Authorization: Bearer <api_key>`
